required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Incidence of Extended-spectrum Î²-lactamase (ESBL) Klebsiella Pneumonia in Patient on Renal Replacement Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: The prevalence of ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia was higher in patient with renal replacement therapy.

primary_outcome.measure: The prevalence of ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia in renal replacement therapy
primary_outcome.description: The prevalence of ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia in renal replacement therapy during hospitalization up to 8 years (from 2004 to 2011)

secondary_outcome.measure: The prevalence of ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia in patient with pneumonia and renal replacement therapy
secondary_outcome.description: The prevalence of ESBL Klebsiella pneumoina in patient with pneumonia and renal replacement therapy during hospitalization up to 8 years (from 2004 to 2011)

arm_group.description: All the patient who's the culture result showed ESBL(+) Klebsiella pneumonia in any site during hospitalization
All the patient who's the culture result showed ESBL(-) Klebsiella pneumonia in any site during hospitalization

intervention.description: renal replacement therapy : hemodialysis and/or CRRT(continuous renal replacement therapy )

study_pop.textblock: The patients had admitted in single center

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The age of patient was between 18 yrs and 79 yrs.
- The patient who showed Klebsiella pneumonia in 1st culture result of any site during hospitalization
Exclusion Criteria:
- The level of serum albumin was below 2.0 or over 5.0
- The level of AST or ALT was 2 times of normal level or the level of bilirubin was over 2.0 mg/dL during 1month.
- The level of Body mass index was below 15 or over 30
- Pregnancy

facility.name: Inje University Seoul Paik hospital Instituional Board Review

responsible_party.investigator_title: Nephrology division, Department of Internal Medicine
